div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.)
N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.-P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 36, New Broad-street. E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS CO., LIMITED. (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, EC.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, APRIL 10, 1905..

div.head: THE NAVAL BATTLE.
div.p: All our telegrams show that the Russian and Japanese fleets will soon be within range of one another's guns, and that a great naval battle is imminent, for the Russians have passed Singapore and the warships of both Powers are reported to have been sighted in the Straits of Malacca. For the next few hours the whole civilised world will be engaged in speculating on the Russians' chances of success against the squadron commanded by Admiral Togo. On paper the Russian fleet is a formidable force, in spite of the presence of some weak units, such as the "Dimitri Donskoi" and the "Almaz," which never made her legend speed, and was originally intended to serve as Admiral Alexeieff's yacht. The four battleships of the "Suvoroff' class, the "Oslabya" and the cruisers "Olez," "Izumrud" and "Jemtchug," are modern and formidable vessels, and the "Navarin" and 'Lissoi Veliki," though old, are heavily armed and armoured vessels. The rest are not worth much against opponents who can shoot straight, and the fourth squadron's composition renders it unlikely that it will lie in the line with Rodjestvensky's force. Of the vessels that compose it, "Nicolai I." is old and slow, and the three little ironclads of the "Senjavin" class would probably hamper the squadron greatly in the day of battle. To begin with, they are low freeboard vessels and would find it hard to fight their turret guns in anything like a sea. Their speed is also not a strong point and they bave very low bunker capacity: finally, they suffer from their lack of trotection-they are vulnerable everywhere above the belt, for their three turrets have no armoured bases in the form of a redoubt, only an armoured hoist which would not prevent shells bursting under the turrets from injuring their supports and perhaps causing them to settle down on the lower deck or thereabouts, to the great peril of the ship. All these considerations make it probable that the Russian leader will use them as a guard for his portentously large convoy, and it will be interesting to see whether he leaves his spare colliers and slow transports at Diego Garcia or some island in the Indian Ocean to await them or waits for them in the Indian Ocean and, when he finds the Japanese, leaves them with his colliers and fights unhampered. There is another course open to him, namely, to go ahead and trust to his ships to damage the Japanese so much that the fourth squadron will be able to get through to Vladivostok with part at least of the first three divisions.

Altogether the situation, assuming that Russian Admiral pushes on, is decic edly. plex. He has two advantages: a large of routes, for there are half-a-dozen streits tween Timor and Java which he may select, and a superiority in large armoured battleships and heavy guns. Against this the Japanese have a superiority in modern armoured vessels, for their armoured cruisers have done good service in the line and their crews and officers have the confidence engendered by success and the practical experience of warfare that their opponents lack. We therefore doubt the Russian Admiral's capacity to inflict a defeat on Togo's fleet, unless the Japanese losses have been far more severe than they confess. Even in that case a partial success would leave the Russians in a worse position, especially if it involved the loss of any large proportion of their colliers. Their nearest base is Vladivostok, while the Japanese can fall back on Formosa for coal and supplies and dock injured vessels in their ports. Altogether the chances are decidedly in favour of Admiral Togo but the Russians have the gam instinct and realise that while failure the them little worse off, a victory might ceivably change the course of the war.

div.head: BRIGHTON ELECTORAL DISASTER.
div.p: GOVERNMENT RESOLVED TO
REMAIN IN OFFICE.
LONDON, April 8.

Mr. Gerard Balfour, speaking at Leeds, said that, though he did not wish to minimise the importance of the electoral disaster at Brighton there was no justification for the Opposition's opinion that the Government ought to resign. The Government was resolved to remain in office as long as it possessed the confidence of the House. (Reuter.)

div.head: RESERVOIR CATASTROPHE AT MADRID.
div.p: 400 CASUALTIES.
MADRID, March 8.

The face of a huge reservoir, which is being constructed outside the town, collapsed this morning. It is believed there are 400 casualties. By 1.15 p.m. 80 dead had been recovered. The nearest hospitals are crowded with injured The King and the Ministers hastened to the spot. His Majesty was directing the rescue operations for over an hour. (Reuter.)
MADRID, April 8. A water reservoir in course of construction has collapsed, burying 435 workmen. One hundred bodies have already been recovered.
(Havas.)

div.head: THE INDIAN EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: BOMBAY, April 8.
The number of Gurkhas killed at Dharmsals
is now stated to be 500. Three missionaries perished in the ruins of the Mission House & (Reuter.)
Dangra.

div.head: CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE.
div.p: PARIS, April 8.
The Chamber of Deputies has urgently passed a vote in favour of the separation of the Churches from the State,
(Havas.)

div.head: MAXIM GORKI'S TRIAL.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, April 8. Maxim Gorki will be tried on May 16. (H)

div.head: MEETING OF THE FLEETS. RUSSIANS AND JAPS CLOSING. ENGAGEMENT EXPECTED.

div.p: Steamers arriving here report the sighting of both Russian and Japanese warships in the Straits. An engagement is expected. (Reuter.)
The Standard learns from Singapore that 27 warships, believed to be Japanese, have been sighted emerging 70 miles to the south west of Penang. (Reuter.)
The British S.S. Tara reports that she sighted 17 Russian ships 130 miles north of Singapore. (Reuter.)
The Russian warships, including 25 transports, are now passing Singapore, steering north east. (Reuter.)

The Baltic fleet, composed of 6 battleships, 9 scullers, 8 destroyers, 3 converted Hamburg-American liners, 3 volunteer ships, 16 colliers, one salvage ship and one hospital ship was steaming at a speed of 8 knots. The fleet showed evidence of a long voyage in tropical waters.All the ships had seaweed along their waterline. The fleet passed 7 miles out and, consequently, exchanged no salutes. The Russian Consul visited the Vice Admiral's ship and conversed from a launch without going on board. The fleet was burning soft coal giving off tremendous smoke which was visible for miles. The fleets submarine men were at their posts all day, and on the alert, and the fleet disappeared eastwards at 5 o'clock in the afternoon. There is no further news regarding the Baltic fleet. (Reuter.)

The Baltic fleet mentioned yesterday did include the most important fighting units, the flagship "Kniaz Suvaroff," the "Imperial Alexander II," and the "Borodino"-with the implement of cruisers and destroyers. Their whereabouts are unknown. (Reuter.)
The China squadron is preparing for sea. H.M.S. cruiser "Sutlej" sails for Singapore today. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KING'S CRUISE. ARRIVAL AT PORT MAHON.

div.p: The King and Queen have left for Port Mahon. (Reuter.)
The King and' Queen of England have arrived here. (Reuter.)
King Edward has arrived and was greatly cheered. (Havas.)

The Situation in Crete is more serious in consequence of the elections. The British cruiser "Juno," with British, French, and Italian detachments, has gone to Selinos, where disturbances are taking place. (Reuter.)
Several members of the Moscow Medical Congress have been arrested. (Reuter.)
Rt. Hon. Sir Francis Henry Jeune (Lord St. Helier) and Lord Chelmsford are dead. (R.)
Association.—Ireland v. Wales. Two goals each. (Reuter.)

ALWAYS IN STOCK LARGE ASSORTMENT OF ENGLISH PROPRIETARY ARTICLES AND SPECIALTIES. CAIRO GRAND HAMMAM. Near Shepard's AND Continental Hotels. Turkish Baths, Plain Baths, X RAYS, Electric Light Baths. GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA. 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED

div.head: THE WAR. TWELVE HOURS FIGHT JAPANS TURNING MOVEMENT.

div.p: Linievitch reports a 12 hours fight on the 4th inst. to the north of Csangtufu. The Japanese losses are considerable. The Russians lost 10 men. (Reuter.)
There is no doubt that the Japanese are attempting a turning movement under the orders of General Oku. (Havas.)

On the occasion of the regimental fates, Generals Kuropatkin and Linievitch telegraphed to the Emperor reporting the splendid bearing of the troops, whose devotion to the throne is unbounded and whose confidence in an ultimate future victory is fervent and unshakeable. (Reuter.)

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ending Saturday 42 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt, as against 4,205 deaths during the corresponding period last year.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
div.p: We may remind those interested that the statutory general meeting of this Chamber will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, tomorrow at 4 p.m.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL
div.p: 14 vessels passed through the Canal on the 6th inst. 11 of which were British, 2 French, 1 German. The day's receipts were frs. 409,488.67 making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 2,049,625.15.

div.head: THE WAKF'S ADMINISTRATION
div.p: has appointed Maitre Frederick W. Simond, the well known member of the bar of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunals, to the important position of official counsel to that administration. This selection has given great satisfaction.

div.head: MENA HOUSE DANCE
div.p: The last small dance of the season at Mena House Hotel will take place this evening at 9.30 o'clock. There will be a special late tramway service on this occasion. Mr. A. Bracale's orchestra will play during dinner and later on the terrace.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: A special gala performance is to be given this evening in honor of H. R. H. the Duke of the Abruzzi and for the benefit of the unfortunate artistes of Gatti's circus troupe. The crew of the Italian cruiser are to be present at the performance, which will be taken part in by several artistes of Gatti's circus.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL CHAMBER OF NAVIGATION
div.p: At a general meeting of the members of the International Chamber of Shipping, held on Saturday, the committee which has been in office since the creation of the Chamber, was unanimously re-elected for a further period of three years. The committee is composed as follows:-—Messrs. J. Ricard,president; F. Allen and G. Barker, vice-presidents ; E Minotto, secretary ; F. Baldovino, Th. Ivanoff, H. de Pitner, and A.Stross, members.

div.head: THE BANDMANN DALLAS OPERA COMPANY
div.p: The long-expected return visit of this excellent combination is now definitely announced in our advertising columns. An exceptionally attractive programme has been arranged, including all the latest musical comedy successes from London, and commencing with "A Country Girl" on Saturday, 22nd inst. The Khedive, the Earl of Cromer, and Brig General G.M. Bullock have given their patronage to the performances, which will be held at the Khedivial Opera House. The prices, considering the expense of such a large company, are most reasonable, and even off these subscribers for the eight performances receive 20 percent discount,—a liberal offer which is sure to be fully taken advantage of. The subscription opens tomorrow at the box office of the Khedivial Opera House. This time a thoroughly good orchestra has been secured, made up almost entirely of the Opera House orchestra.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. "Anatolia" is expected here from Odessa on Thursday night, and will begin loading for Liverpool immediately.

The Moss line "Tabor" sailed from Liverpool on Friday afternoon last, and is due here about the 21st inst. with passengers, mails, and general cargo. the Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Senegal," from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Sunday afternoon and is due here tomorrow.
The S.S. "Ararat," of the Papayanni Line, left for Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The S.S. "City of Khios," of the Papayanni Line, arrived at Liverpool this morning.
The S.S. "Belgravian," of the Papayanni Line, is expected from Constantinople tomorrow morning and will leave for Liverpool in a few days.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM. NEW THEORY OF STRAIN EXPLAINED.
div.p: There has hardly been time yet to have received the criticisms of the wise men of Europe and America on the recent decisions of the Egyptian Government to postpone—for tho present-the completion, as some eminent men are pleased to call it, of the dam at Assouan by increasing the height by some eighteen feet. Such men do not care to commit themselves in a hurry when a fresh proposition, of a nature such as this, is first put before them. We must have patience yet before we can expect to receive the general opinions of scientific authorities.

For one, however, who has been familiar with all the details of this great work from the commencement, as is tho case with the consulting engineer, Sir Benjamin Baker, it is not surprising that he should give the public the benefit of his views, however slight, as early as possible. They have indeed a right to expect it. Sir Benjamin has informed a reporter of the "Daily Mail" that this decision of tho Egyptian authorities is by no means entirely due to tho theories recently propounded by the learned mathematicians. Primarily it is due, according to Sir Benjamin, to the fact that during his recent visit he found it neccessary to advise the authorities that the apron, or floor of masonry, a small portion of which was put down last year, must be extended along the whole length of the dam, so as to protect the base of the structure from any mischief in future, such as might be caused by the great rush of water through the sluices which at times, when it rises to the sixty feet level, has such a pressure that it flows through the sluices at the rate of over 36 miles an hour.
The diagrams below, which I have taken from the "Daily Mail," will better enable your readers to understand this:—

In the opinion of several engineers with whom I have discussed the question, this alone is sufficient reason for "going slow" for the present, although some think the necessity for this work should have been foreseen from the commencement and therefore undertaken earlier. However that may be, the decision is considered a wise one, if there were no other reason to justify it. But there is yet another reason, for some months ago the theory of Mr. Atcherley and Professor Karl Pearson that the stresses are also in a vertical direction as well as horizontal, was propounded in a pamphlet, which, as soon as it came into the hands of the Egyptian authorities set them, "a-thinking." Their consulting engineer was called out to examine and discuss the theory on tho spot, with the result as is known.

I have seen some hard things said of the Egyptian authorities as to their action being too sudden, and influenced more by the present condition of land speculation than the question of the stability of the dam. These ideas have found little favor among those who know Egypt,—quite the contrary. It is thought that the country should be congratulated as having a strong and capable Government, who at once took the public into their confidence, and told them the true state of affairs. Nothing could justify the Government in taking the slightest risk on what for Egypt is a most interesting question. If anything were to happen to the dam—of which now there is not the slightest chance—it would mean that, the Blue Nile would in future would have to be spelt Blue Ruin, so fearful would be the consequences of its escape.

No doubt this has been a disappointment to several people, who are interested in helping to develop the uncultivated lands of Egypt, and who were rightly expecting that the additional supply of water would soon enable them to do this. Some of these are adversely criticizing the action of the Government, as for the moment they have received a cold douche. But are they justified, in face of all the facts which have been given to the public? If they only have patience they will get all the water they want, and this sooner than is generally anticipated. Land companies, which are started under proper auspices and conditions, will no doubt do a great deal of good for this country; for they not only find the necessary capital and organization which the fellaheen have not got, but they also bring the land into cultivation and a paying condition, with a view to selling it to the natives afterwards, so that eventually the people will own a still further quantity of land than at present. This is all in the right direction and "marking time," which the "dam question" now calls for, can only be for the good of the country, from whatever point of view it is looked at.

div.head: THE AGRICULTURAL BANK.
div.p: The following calculation, received from a Cairo .correspondent, will be of interest to the shareholders of tho above company:—
Sinking Fund „ „ = 225,000
Less expenses, say, £70,000 (They were £45,000 last year)
Statutory Reserve5 % on interest collected 22,300
National Bank of Egypt 9,600
Div. to Shareholders 5% on £1,250,000 . 62,500
4 Dividend to PreT Shares 50,000
3* '/ to £2.590,000 of Bonds plus * % Sinking Fund 100,000 314,600
of which half goes to Deferred Shareholders leaving £67,700
This sum is sufficient to distribute a supplementary dividend of nearly 5*%, which, added to the original, 5 %, divided gives a total dividend which could be given to present shareholders of 10.45 %.

These figures do not include the net profit earned on overdrafts at the National Bank of Egypt, which is an unknown and variable quantity, but which must nevertheless be considered as an important factor in any estimate of profits.

The effect of issuing £1,250,000 new shares of £5 each will be as follows. Existing shareholders will lend another £5, making a total of £10 advanced by each shareholder on the old and new issues. The new issue put out at 9%. will yield a gross profit of £112,500
Deduct 5% dividend on the new issue £62,500 . 2% for expenses revolved by the extension of the business £87,500 £25,000 -------- £25,000
We have £25,000 to divide equally among deferred shareholders and the combined issues of ordinary shares.
The position will then be as follows.

5% dividend on original issue of 1,250,000 £62,500 * of "Surplus profit of £135,400 available for distribution £67,700 5% dividend to 2nd issue of £1,250,000 £62,500 * of surplus profit earned on1-2nd issue of ordinary shares £12,500 £205,200-
or sufficient to pay a dividend of about 8*/, on the total issued ordinary share capital of £2,800,000;

Assuming that these figures are correct, with the price of money at 4%, if, as we believe, one new share is to be offered at par to every existing shareholder for each share of the old issue in his possession, the combined values of the eld and new share will be at least £20 and the value of the old share to-day £15.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST & INVESTMENT.
div.p: This morning, the subscription for the-Egyptian Trust and Investment (Limited) opened at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank in Cairo and Alexandria and the rush to subscribe is simply phenomenal.

div.head: ANOTHER EGYPTIAN FLOTATION.
div.p: The City Notes of the "Globe" of Monday last foreshadow a new Egyptian flotation. After giving some details as to the Egyptian Trust and Investment, our London contemporary remarks: —this is not the only flotation of importance which is imminent in the Egyptian market. A concern of the first magnitude is being talked of in certain City circles, which would own various concessions and have a total capital of £600,000, of which £450,000 would be allocated to working capital. It remains to be seen, of course, whether theo nature of the concessions is such as to afford sufficient justification for the expenditure of so large a sum upon them.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND INVESTMENT
div.p: The allotment of shares and the posting of letters of allotment,- letters of regret, and cheque*, wore effected by midnight on Sunday. The allotment arrangements were placed in the hands of Messrs. Russell and Kerr, and the rapidity with which the operation was effected has given great satisfaction in financial circles.

div.head: THE HELLENIC BANK.
div.p: The first official meeting of the provisional board of directors of the new Hellenic Bank of Cairo was held yesterday morning at the offices of Rostovitz Bey. The capital will probably be increased to £200,000 sterling.

div.head: NILE NAVIGATION.
div.p: Nile traffic is increasing every day, and the number of freight barges and tourist steamers is always on the increase. There is, however, plenty of room for development both in the freight and passenger services, and the Germans intend to have their share of this lucrative and growing business. The Hamburg-America line has decided to construct six river steamers of light draught for use on the Nile. The vessels will be luxuriously fitted.

div.head: A REGRETTABLE INCIDENT. SCHOLARS ON STRIKE.
div.p: A regrettable incident, or rather a series of incidents, has taken place at the Polytechnic School at Ghizeh. It appears that last Tuesday a pupil, on being told to sit on a certain bench, objected that there was water on it, and, backed the objection by comments that resulted in his being reported to the head master.

It seems that be refused to apologize and was "sent down" for a week, whereupon a number of his fellow students sent in a petition on his behalf. The petition was not granted and his sympathetic friends struck work for a day. This was too much, and the writer of the petition was also "sent down" on Thursday last.

Friday was a dies non, and on Saturday the pupils returned in the morning and having arranged a plan of campaign departed in the afternoon, and on to the present have not returned. Only four appear to have declined to join the strike.
The situation is not pleasant and great sympathy is felt with Dr. Mackenzie, the head master, whose relations with his pupils have always been excellent.
It is impossible to say what will be the upshot of this movement among the pupils. We are inclined to think that it has been engineered from Cairo "pour embeter les Anglais."

div.head: MEHKEMEH SHARIEH REFORM.
div.p: At a meeting of the General Assembly, held yesterday, a motion was carried urging the reform of the Mehkemeh Sharieh. This is especially interesting in view of the fact that the General Assembly, on the last occasion that it was convoked, supported a resolution to the effect that the Mehkemeh Sharieh needed no refund whatever.

div.head: GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: On Saturday the General Assembly approved the following proposals which it has decided to transmit to the Government:
1. To construct drains in Cairo.
2. To reduce the fees on wakfs, those of "ailoula and insha' and those on mortgages.
3. To construct the Esneh barrage at Jebel Sireg (Edfou) and raise pumps in Upper Egypt.
4. To make the El Ramadi Canal 'Sefi.'
5. To lay a railway between Nag Hamadi and Edfou.
6. To lay an agricultural light line between Esneh and Abou Shousha.
7. To construct a permanent weir at Damietta.
8. To widen the Damietta Boghaz.
9. To create registration bureaux in the provinces.
10. To modify the Sharaki regulations.
11. To reform the Mehkemeh Sharieh.
The demand for the creation of a Municipality at Cairo was rejected by the Assembly after some discussion.

div.head: AL AZHAR.
div.p: A petition has been addressed to the Grand Mufti by several hundred students of Al Azhar, begging him to resume his course lectures on the Koran.

div.head: THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: This morning Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, and Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, called on the Duke of the Abruzzi, on board the "Liguria," in order to return the Prince's visit to, the Gouvernorat on Thursday last.

The Italian colony at Alexandria deserve to be heartily congratulated on the success of the ball given last night in honor of the visit of H.R.H. the Duke of the Abruzzi and the officers of the Italian cruiser "Liguria." The New Khedivial Hotel had been elaborately prepared for the occasion. The ball-room was graced by a large portrait of the King of Italy, set up in front of the entrance, surrounded by flowers. Nearly a thousand invitations had been sent out and there was a most brilliant and representative gathering of all the leading members of Alexandrian society.
The ball began at 9.30 p.m. and dancing was kept up with great vigour until an early hour this morning. A well-stocked buffet was prepared for the guests and a splendid supper was served at midnight.

The committee of organisation was constituted as follows : — Judge Commendatore Moriondo, of the Mixed Court of Appeal, chairman ; Commendatore Paoluoci, M. Luigi Stagni, M. Amabile Cumbo, Dr. Valensia, Dr. Torella, M. A. Tilche, M. Piha, Avvocate Pennazzi, M. L. Bianchi, M. G. Degiarde, M. Nicholas Sabba, M. Bellantuonis.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
div.p: At a meeting of the council of the Suez Canal Company, held on the 3rd inst, Dr. L.H. Ruyssenaers, Secretary-General of the Hague Court of Arbitration and former Dutch Minister at Lisbon, was selected to fill the vacancy on the board caused by the death of Mr. Auslijn, formerly Dutch Consul-General in Egypt.

div.head: A LESSON FROM SPAIN.
div.p: The terrible catastrophe, announced in our telegrams from Madrid, of the bursting of a huge reservoir with a large loss of life, should afford food for grave reflection to all those who consider that the recent action of the Egyptian Government, in refraining from heightening the Assouan Dam, is a sign of needless timorousness.

div.head: RUSSIAN REFUGEES.
div.p: At noon today the German Lloyd "Princess Alice" arrived, having on board some 150 odd Russian refugees from Port Arthur. These were all transferred in lighters to the Russian S.S. "Imperatrice Maria," in waiting. This last is to sail during Saturday morning for Odessa.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY.
div.p: Today being the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence, a great fete has been in course of preparation. This morning a crowded Greek church testified to the great interest taken in the fete, and with the Greek consular officials in full regalia, with numerous other uniforms, a distinctly interesting and novel sight was the result.
This evening a special piece was played by a Greek theatrical company now here, at the Eldorado, the official representatives of the Greek Government gracing the theatre with their presence.
After the play a public ball was held in the auditorium at which considerably over 700 people assisted, principally as spectators.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: H.M.S. "Mutine," sloop, left Port Said this morning homeward bound from the Australian station, where her place will be taken by H.M.S. "Pegasus," which left Suez on Friday.
H.M.S. "Diadem," first class cruiser, arrived on Saturday, She is bound to China to relieve H.M.S. "Amphitrite."
H.M.S. "Pylades," third-class cruiser, Commander da Costa, is now in the Canal, homeward bound from Australia.
The French cruiser "Chateaurenault" (Capt de Castries) arrived at Port Said early Saturday morning from Colombo bound for Cherbourg. She has a crew of 630 men and carries 8 guns.
The German despatch vessel "Lorely" (Capt and Lieut. Bruneninghaus arrived at Port Said at 8 a.m. today from Alexandria and leaves at 5.30 p.m. for Jaffa.

div.head: SALVAGE OF THE "CONGAL."
div.p: Operations have at last been started on the Norwegian ship "Congal", which, it will be remembered was sunk in harbour by the Harrison liner "Craftsman'' and has for a long time lain there, causing great inconvenience to the Canal Company. The Constantinople Salvage Association were approached by the owners and insurers of the vessel and two of their salvage steamers have been here, but left again without doing anything, and it appears that they asked £60,00 for raising her. This sum was not accepted. She is insured for £5,000 and is vessel of some thirty years old, so It Is easily understood that the Insurers would have nothing to do with the salving of her at such a cost. The result was that a court case was started, and she was handed over to the Canal Company to do what they wished with her.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Empress Eugenie has arrived at Marseilles from Egypt and is making a stay at Cap Martin.
The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire have arrived in London from Egypt.

Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, and his wife and son, are leaving Alexandria on June 17 by the Austrian Lloyd steamer for Bridisi. His Excellency will travel through Italy and France and then will proceed to England, where he will remain about a month. His Excellency will leave his son in England in order to complete his education at the University.

A lunch was given by the Circle Artistique at Cairo on Saturday morning in honor of Coquelin Cadet with whom were Mme Moreno, Mile Bouchatal, M. Jean Coqnelin, and M. Montoux. Among those present were Prince Haidar, Comanos Pasha, Caetelli Bey, M. L Cattani, Dr. G. Veronoff, Me. Carton fle Wiart Margosoff.Bey, Mahmoud Bey Sadik, M. L. Betrand, M. G. Vidal, M. P. Oziol, and many others.
Mr. Constantino Meimararhi, Managing Director of Walker and Meimarechi Ltd., has arrived at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, for a few days.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management. 11.11.906 EDEN PALACE HOTEL, CAIRO. Open all the year round. ELECTRIC LIGHT, -LIFT.- MODERATE CHARGE.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
SERVITUDES NATURELLES
La Daira Toussoun Pacha contre The Aboukir Land Company Limited.

La Daira Toussoun Pacha, dont les terrains se trouvent séparés du canal Mahmoudieh par les propriétés de la Cie Anglaise d'Aboukir, est entrée en pourparlers avec celle-ci pour en obtenir un passage d'eau sur son terrain, mais, n'ayant pu s'entendre avec elle sur le chiffre de l'indemnité, le point en litige a du être porté devant Thémis.

Le Tribunal, se basant sur l'art. 54 de la loi, reconnait l'obligation pour la Cie de se soumettre aux servitudes naturelles, mais le mon tant de l'indemnité étant une question plus délicate, il a cru nécessaire de nommer trois experts pour le fixer; d'une part, en effet, le servant, qui est en ce cas la Cie d'Aboukir, ne doit retirer aucun profit de la servitude et de l'autre, l'indemnité doit être complète et adéquate.
Voici le dispositif du jugement:-

Par ces motifs, ouï le M. P. en son avis et statuant publiquement et contradicto:rement, dit pour droit que la Cie défenderesse doit sur son terrain le passage de l'eau nécessaire au fond de la Daira demanderesse.

Et avant de régler l'établissement de ce passage et l'indemnité préalable qui sera due ( à la Compagnie défenderesse, nomme commet experts les sieurs Lascaris, Savorgnan et Ismalum, lesquels auront pour mission, serment préalablement prêté,

1° D'indiquer quels sont les travaux à faire pour l'établissement du passage par les terrains S de la Cie défenderesse des eaux nécessaires à l'irrigation des terrains de la Daïra deman-1 deresse, de façon à ce que ce passage soit le moins dommageable possible pour le fonds ser-
vant.

2° De fixer l'indemnité qui peut être dûe à la Cie défenderesse à raison de l'établissement ( de cette servitude, en tenant compte tant de la valeur du terrain empris que de la dépréciation éventuelle du fonds servant ou de toute autre cause de dominage et de manière à ce que sans tirer profit de la servitude en question, la Cie défenderesse soit néanmoins indemnisée de tout préjudice subi.

3° De dire si les terrains dont s'agit comportent l'établissement de drains destinés à l'écoulement des eaux des terrains de la Daïra dans le siphon actuellement en construction sous le canal Mahmoudieh à l'Ezbet Kourchid, et dans ce cas dans quelle proportion la Daïra peut être équitablement tenue de contribuer aux frais de construction du dit siphon. Pour le rapport d'expertise déposé être par les parties conclu et le Tribunal statué comme en justice il appartiendra.

div.head: Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte
div.p: Nous avons annoncé dernièrement la nomination de Monsieur Attilio Ninci comme Directeur de la Société au Caire.

A cette occasion, le personnel de l'Agence d'Alexandrie, Agence que Monsieur A. Ninci a dirigée avec tant de succès pendant trois ans, a offert, samedi dernier, à son ancien Chef, en témoignage de reconnaissance, un magnifique souvenir et une adresse de félicitations.

Monsieur Ninci, profondément ému de cette manifestation de sympathie, a vivement remercié les employés de l'Agence, en leur assurant que c'était avec le plus grand regret qu'il se voyait obligé de se séparer d'aussi dévoués collaborateurs dont il garderait toujours le meilleur souvenir.

Monsieur Ninci a, en outre, félicité le personnel de l'heureuse idée qu'il a eue de choisir, pour cette manifestation, le moment de la présence de Monsieur de la Bouglise, administrateur, auquel Monsieur Ninci est lié par la plus vive effection et le plus profond dévoue-
ment.

En terminant, Monsieur Ninci a dit que sa promotion devait être considérée par les employés de la Société, comme une garantie pour l'avenir et une marque de l'intérêt et de la bienveillance dont le personnel est sans cesse l'objet de la part du Conseil d'Administration et tout particulièrement de son Président, Monsieur E. Cronier,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demie)
Par suite des réalisations qui continuent la cote s'inscrit encore en baisse.

La Banque Nationale tombe de 27 1/2 à 27 1/8, l'Agricole de 13 7/16 à 13 1/16,la Daïra de 27 5/16 à 27 1/16, l'Anglo-American Nile de 5 15/16 à 5 3/4, l'Alexandria Water Com; pany de 16 1/2 à 16 3/8 et la Delta Light de 14 1/4 à 14 3/16.
Les petites valeurs sont également en réaction: la Delta Land de 3 7/8 à 3 3/4, les Oasis de 17/32 à 1 3/16, les Markets de 23/3
à 23 et la Salt & Soda de 40 à 39/6. En Estates on a dépassé à un moment donné 1 1/4 mais en clôture on est retombé à 13/16. Seul l'Investment est un peu plus ferme à 2 1/4 vendeurs.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chanber,

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES.

Messieurs les actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le Samedi six Mal 1905 à 4 heures de l'après-midi, au Siège Social, au Caire, afin de délibérer sur la proposi-. tion suivante : Augmentation du Capital Social et modification de l'article
10 des Statuts.

Tout actionnaire possédant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part à l'Assemblée Générale à condition de déposer ses actions dans l'un des lieux ci-après désignés où il lui sera délivré une carte d'admission.
En Egypte, Cinq jours au moins avant le le jour de la réunion, soit le 1er Mai, au plus tard:
au Siège Social, au Caire;
à la Banque Impériale Ottomane; à l'Anglo- Egyptian Bank; au Crédit Lyonnais;
à la Bank of Egypt;
au Caire
ou
à Alexandrie.
En Europe, au plus tard le 27 Avril :
à Paris et à Marseille, aux bureaux de la

"Société Marseillaise"; en Italie, dans les bureaux de la "Banca Commerciale Italiana"; à Londres, à l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 et 5. King William Street. E.C. L'Assemblée, pour pouvoir délibérer valablement devant réunir la moitié des actions émises, Messieurs les actionnaires sont priés de faire le dépôt de toutes leurs actions.
Le Gouverneur: Elwin Palmer. 25717-12.A.2
Le Caire, le 5 Avril 1905.

div.head: ADMINISTRATION DES POSTES
div.p: AVIS

Les demandes de distribution à domicile au Caire et à Alexandrie augmentant continuellement, il est absolument nécessaire que, sur les correspondances qui doivent bénéficier de ce mode de distribution, dans les deux villes précitées, le nom de la rue et le numéro du domicile du destinataire soient clairement indiqués. Si la rue n'est pas dénommée, le nom du quartier doit être donné.
Le public est prié de se conformer à ces instructions pour éviter des retards ou des erreurs dans la distribution des correspondan-
ces.

div.head: SALE OF BRITISH ARMY STORES.
div.p: A sale by auction of the following stores will take place at the Ordnance Depot Mustapha Pasha, at 10 a.m. on Friday next the 14th inst. viz :-
Carts, Trolley, Water Barrels, Sovels, Spades, Tents, Clasp Knives, Old Metal, etc.
Lists can be obtained and stores viewed on application to the Acting Ordance Officer.

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.

div.head: BOURSE KHEDIVIALE
div.p: Remarques sur le marché du disponible et
des contrats.
Samedi, le 8 avril 1905.
Cotons Disponible.-Il y a eu beaucoup de ralentissement dans la demande et quoique les prix

n'offrent que peu de changements, le marché n'en est pas moins en tendance plutôt faible. Les provenances Haute-Egypte de Good Fair et au-dessous sont les seules qui aient joui de quelque faveur et dont la cote a enregistré une petite hausse.
Franco-station.-On n'en parle pas. Contrats. Nouvelle récolte. Maintenant que la vieille récolte réactionne, le novembre
montre beaucoup de soutien, ce qui ne surprend guère du moment qu'il avait résisté au mouvement de hausse. L'activité pourtant n'y est pas grande.
Récolte actuelle. Les haussiers, doutant de la réussite de leur manœuvre sur mai, commencent à vouloir sortir, et c'est cette circons-

tance qui a fait baisser les prix et réduit le déport sur juillet à 3/16 de talari. En apparence il y a encore du soutien, mais, en réalité, il y a de la faiblesse et de l'inaction, au point que nous pourrons bien avoir sous peu l'horaire d'eté supprimant les séances de l'après-midi. Beaucoup de courtiers le demandent déjà. Dans la matinée; prix plus haut pour mai tal. 13 9/32 à 5/16; plus bas pour mai 18 1/4 à--
Graines de coton

Disponible.-La demande est modérée et les cours ne parviennent pas à se relever. Contrats.-Nouvelle récolte. On a fini par accompagner l'affichage du prix du mot "nominal", tant les affaires y sont rares. Acheteurs et vendeurs se montrent réservés.

Récolte actuelle.-De temps à autre quelques transactions, mais insuffisantes pour imprimer au marché une animation quelconque. Toutefois, il y a meilleur ton depuis hier, l'influence de la première filière d'avril ayant déjà disparu.
Dans la matinée; prix plus haut pour avril P.T. 54-/— à −/− : plus bas pour avril 53 35/40 à —/—.
Feves
Faute d'arrivages, aucune affaire en disponible.
Quant aux contrats, ils continuent à être complètement négligés.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)

REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
